entry.title: Zoo & Bob Roll
entry.content:
I rode the Zoo hill climb yesterday doing one-legged intervals. That was fun. By some very non-standard definition of fun. When I got to the turn up to the radio towers there was a whole shitload of good (1s and 2s, and expert/pro mtbers) cyclists hanging out; as I rode up, I passed even more on their way down (I don't pass any good cyclists on a hill who are actually going the same direction as me, unless said hill is less than a couple hundred feet long). When I got back down to the turnoff, the huge group was just leaving; Eric Atwood and Nathan were in there and I said hey to them and chatted briefly with Nathan, who said they were off to do another 4000 feet of climbing. Sounded like fun, but I needed to get back to work. Oh, and I wouldn't've had a prayer of keeping up with them -- maybe on the flats but no way on the climbs. Someday... I've lost 13 pounds so far this year and if I can lose another 30 (holy shit that's a big number) I will be able to hang in with the good climbers on hilly training rides. entry.title: The cruelest quarter
entry.content:
Spring in Seattle is like March everywhere else (by a narrow definition of "everywhere else" which here means "other places I have lived": Massachusetts and Connecticut) but all stretched out between January and April. Last week it was 60 degrees and sunny. Yesterday when I finished lifting I walked out into 1/4" hail pellets, complete with thunder and lightning. Today it was about 38 degrees, windy and alternating clouds and sun.

Which might've made for a great ride, if I was Johan Museeuw or something. Unfortunately I'm not, I'm just a schlub whose riding-into-a-headwind skills are lacking and frustration-inducing. I actually had a fairly pleasant ride for the first 3 hours, despite the wind and cold temperatures, but then I got my second flat and didn't have another CO2 cartridge to inflate it. So I had to ride the last 7 miles or so, 5 of which are uphill, on a flat front tire. (parenthetically, I should say that uphill is much better than downhill with a flat front tire, but it prolongs the experience)

I'm home, warm, caffeinated and happy now. But I was unhappy on my ride... did I mention that during the fixing of the first flat, I put my wheel right in a pile of dog shit? I now have a concrete example of a ride "going to shit" which it definitely did right at that point.

Ah, I'll have a better ride tomorrow. And it'll be made much sweeter with the knowledge that I'm passing time towards watching the Patriots destroy the Eagles.

Not as cool as actually riding outside, but still... maybe if I got one of those I could actually stand to ride a trainer for more than 45 minutes. Though I kinda doubt it.

entry.title: Cycling is not a summer sport
entry.content:
It's taken me a while to realize this... for many years I held the idyllic late-June day with green grass and a whisper of a breeze as the Ideal cycling day. It's become apparent to me that I was setting myself up for despair. The ideal day for cycling is windy, gray, spitting rain and probably cold. Why is this ideal? Largely because it is the mode of cycling if you're interested in being in shape to enjoy those idyllic summer days. Beyond that, experiencing all the weather and road conditions and darkness makes the good days stand out that much more.

So: not only does riding in January make you stronger, it provides the days you should enjoy the most.

This is what I keep telling myself.

entry.title: The Land Shark is dead
entry.content:
Long live the Land Shark!

A few months ago, I sent my erstwhile Land Shark -- my favorite bike, my first custom frame, my first Campy-equipped bike -- back to John Slawta, its builder, for a repaint and to fix a small dent in the top tube. I just got a call from George at Il Vecchio. entry.title: Mr. Grumpy
entry.content:
I'm trying to lose a bunch of weight. The way to do this is obvious: eat less and exercise more. So I'm doing both of these things. And losing weight, fast, and getting faster on my bike and in many ways feeling better.

However: it turns out that this particular combination can turn me into a raging asshole. Last night, I rode for 45 minutes on my trainer and was filled with bile and ill-will towards the world and Lindsey in particular. She managed to maintain her humor despite my irreconcilable surliness, which I find unbelievable now but at the time only served to make me yet more angry.

And then this morning (since my seething rage last night I had eaten exactly 1 banana) some dickwad in a shitty old pickup truck towing a giant trailer full of PVC pipe accelerated and swerved towards me as he passed me, missing me by inches (there was no other traffic on the road, and he had plenty of room to pass me safely). If there was any way I could've caught him, I would've done everything in my power to tear him limb from limb, rip open his rib cage, and devour his heart. Seriously.

Now that I've eaten a bagel with lox and a big bowl o' fruit, I feel nothing but serenity and peace. Ahh.

entry.title: Trainin', trainin', trainin'
entry.content:
The rain which was threatening yesterday held off for the duration of my ride, which was a very pleasant surprise. I just rode the Burke from Marymoor up to Bothell & back, nice and easy. Saw a few other folks from the mtb scene out training too; things are picking up.

I'd forgotten what it's like to ride in the presence of other people, though; out in Carnation I'll /maybe/ see one other cyclist per ride. The Burke is a very different story; there's obviously not the general esprits du corps that you get when you see another cyclist in the middle of nowhere, and it is funny to see the castes that exist on the trail, and funny to watch people try to prove their mettle. I'm not anything at all like fast, and yesterday I was going slow even for me, so if you've gotta work at all to pass me, that's funny.

Today was a lifting day, which was a nice respite from the bike but poorly timed since it was 60 degrees and sunny. I got to be one of those people I always make fun of, indoors exercising on a beautiful day. Ah well. At least I have that sublime post-really-good-workout bliss on right now.

entry.title: Back in the groove

entry.title: Cold!
entry.content:
The past few days have been very cold. By that I mean cold for the Seattle area; it was probably 20 degrees this morning when I got on my bike to ride to work. The air was piercing clear and I was pretty excited for an exhilarating ride.

So I coasted down to the Snoqualmie Valley Trail, rode the trail past trees and shrubs coated with frost and backlit by the cold morning sun, turned onto Carnation Farm Road, warmed up on that first little hill before the farm itself, coasted a little bit, started pedalling again and encountered no resistance.

Uh oh.

This felt disconcertingly like when my freehub exploded back in May on Devil's Gulch. Or when my freewheel exploded in Meridian, Mississippi way back when.

I got off to check and sure enough: bi-directional freewheel! The boolean NOT of a fixed gear; it did nothing but coast.

The hub wasn't making the disconcerting grating sounds that my last exploding freehub produced, so that was encouraging. But it definitely wasn't gonna get me anywhere. So I called Lindsey (bless her heart) and she came out to get me; I spent about 15 minutes hopping around trying to stay warm and getting stared at by farmers in their pickups while I waited for her.

Now that it's indoors and warm, my freehub's fine again. I think the grease just got too cold and wouldn't let the pawls engage. I don't know what I'm gonna do for cold-weather riding for the next few days, though; I really want to ride. I could just ride my singlespeed, I guess...

entry.title: First blog from the G5
entry.content:
In what could be seen as a traitorous move but what I prefer to think of as "research", I recently bought a G5 PowerMac.

Holy crap.

This is the greatest machine I've ever used.

Seriously.

You can read all this in other places on the web too, but here's a for-example: I had to open up the computer to add some memory. Now, on a PC that typically requires unscrewing some rickety screws, pulling off the case in a way that makes you wonder what you're breaking, digging through a mess of wires, installing the chips, struggling to put the case back together, and trying to find the screws you just lost. On the G5, there's a substantial metal lever that lies flush with the back of the case. Pull it up and the (heavy) right side panel swings down, revealing a substantial lexan airflow director. That slides out smoothly, then you slide out a beatifully sculpted fan unit (which plugs into the motherboard). Then you insert your memory. There are no wires to move out of the way (in fact, no visible wires in the case), everything is clean and well-crafted (dare I say beautiful), and everything goes back together solidly.

I can't even begin to talk about how much I like the OS right now, except to say that it makes me feel like Zeus, throwing lightning bolts through the ether.

entry.title: Shenandoah 100
entry.content:
I attempted the Shenandoah 100 this past Sunday and to my considerable dismay had to drop out at mile 57. The first 50 miles were great; I felt fairly strong and focused and was having fun on the downhills and relaxed on the climbs. Unfortunately, somewhere between Aid 3 (at mile 46) and aid 4 (at mile 57) all hell broke loose. I think it was something I ate -- I've had small pepperoni sticks as snacks before on long rides and they've been great but this time I think I got one with something I was allergic to in it. I got a terrible headache, felt nauseous, and could barely even walk let alone ride. I was trudging along plotting selling all my bikes and doing something fun -- like, I dunno, playing video games all the time -- for what felt like hours before finally getting out of the woods to Aid 4. I'd made the decision to drop out before I got to Aid 4, but once I got there of course I tried to convince myself to go on; I sat down for a while and drank some Coke, ate some other food, but it just wasn't helping. Finally after a long internal struggle I told a race official I was dropping out and got a ride back to the start/finish.

After hanging out watching (very fast) people finish for a while, I decided to volunteer at Aid 6. Aid 6 is the last aid station on the course; it's at mile 88 and when most people come through here they're /tired/. It was great to help out and see the race from the other side for a while; when you're racing, the volunteers seem like benevolent angels or something; while you're volunteering, the riders (even the slowest) seem like heroes.

So I guess I have two lessons: first, pay attention to ingredients on food. Second, and I think this hurt me a lot too: don't let work interfere with training or at least be honest with myself when it does. For the two weeks before I left on this trip I was swamped with really time-consuming stuff at work that meant I couldn't get out and do my long rides on weekdays, and I just can't let that happen. Work's important but in the overall scheme of things I'll do better work if I can limit my time there and make time for personal things that are important to me. Easier said than done.

Anyway, pictures to follow once I get back to WA.

entry.title: Double Crown attempt
entry.content:
Yesterday I went out to try the Palisades->White Rim->Skookum->Sun Top loop with some folks from the BBTC. I've wanted to try this ride for a long time and when I heard that Bob Bournique was leading it I decided to bail on the final WIM race and do an epic ride instead.

At the very start of the ride I realized my front brake had been leaking a little bit of hydraulic fluid, and I could bring it to the bar without fully locking the front wheel. I probably should've paid attention to that, but I just thought, "well, it'll warm up and the brake will tighten." Um, yeah. Good science. If you're ever wondering if that's a viable strategy, it isn't.

I had a lot of fun on the climb up Corral Pass -- I really do enjoy climbing in the sun, early in the day, helmet off -- just zoning and cranking along. However, I'd forgotten how tough Palisades is. On the way down, I had one of my scariest crashes ever. I'd like to blame my wonky brakes for that but in fact it was my own lack of skill: I went off the side of the trail on one of the steeper sidecut parts (after the hike-a-bike through the rockfall), somersaulted about 3 times, bounced off some trees, hit some deadfall, lost some skin, got some ugly bruises, and -- best of all -- ripped a significant portion of the seat of my bike shorts off. That made for an embarrassing ride back to the Buck Creek trailhead (where we'd parked) -- thankfully only about 100 yards of the ride was on the road; the rest was on trail and I rode at the back...

Back at the cars, I put on my (non-riding) shorts over my bike shorts, we hung out for a while eating, then took off down Skookum. If it wasn't obvious from above, I should mention that I'm a terrible technical rider -- I love smooth singletrack but I completely fall apart on trails like Palisades and Skookum. So I was already in a world of hurt, feeling woozy from crashing, I'd been riding for 5 hours, and then I got to tackle Skookum. Bleagh. I made it through with only one endo.

We hung out at the end of Skookum for a little bit -- probably longer than was strictly necessary; the long climb to Sun Top was looming in front of us and nobody seemed in a particular hurry. I know I wasn't. Once we got going I started thinking, "OK, this isn't bad." But the first mile of the climb is pretty much flat, so of course it wasn't too bad. And yes, once the climb began in earnest, it was bad. It was hot. The climb was steep, and I was full of bonk and misery. I swear I was riding cross-eyed and could hardly hold a straight line; shots of Gu and lots of water didn't make a difference. One of the guys, Ken, apparently took pity on me and rode alongside talking with me. I'm afraid I was terrible company. So after about 4 miles of climbing, I bailed. Ken was remarkably understanding and at the time I appreciated his not trying to convince me to go on -- in retrospect I wonder how bad I looked...

I had a nice coast down to 410 and the a hellish ride back on the false flat of 410 to the Buck Creek Trailhead. I was so wrecked that even taking the front wheel off my bike to put it in my car seemed like a lot of work.

Of course, in the bright light of a new day I feel like a complete wimp and riding sounds like fun again now. I'm gonna go try this ride again next weekend, alone, and see how it goes. I might do Ranger Creek instead of Palisades to make it a little easier on myself, though.

It was a beautiful day for a ride, and until I crashed I was having a great time. The views from up near Noble Knob were absolutely incredible -- Rainier was out in full force yesterday. Everyone on the ride was great -- Bob Bournique knows how to put together an awesome ride, that's for sure.

Here are some pictures from the ride. I always think I'm getting more good pictures than I actually am (I think I'm at zero here...). Anyway, click on the pictures for bigger versions.

This one is on the White River trail, right before the start of the Corral Pass road climb.




This is up at the top of Corral Pass, starting down the trail towards Palisades.




A couple of miles into the Sun Top climb. My camera's lens was all foggy (it was in my jersey pocket) but reflects well how I actually felt at this point.

Raced at the track on Monday and had a blast. Theresa and Greg were there and Theresa ended up in my group. We did 3 races: point a lap, scratch, and a 3x3 points race. In the point-a-lap, I tried a breakaway on the first lap, stayed away for one lap, got caught, then Theresa and I got away from everyone on the 3rd lap and split the remaining points. Theresa won because she won the final sprint. Theresa won the scratch race from a field sprint. Theresa won and I got second in every sprint in the points race. Awesome night of racing. I really can't wait to race more on the track.

I also met John Fischer, a msftie who races (really well) on the track. When he met me he said, "huh, you're Mo? I thought you were way bigger & uglier!" I'll take that as a compliment, I guess.
Here's a picture from yesterday's ride. Unfortunately Rainier's all blown out in the background.

I had big plans for a ride today -- I was going to ride Sun Top, then Ranger Creek, for a 40ish mile ride with about 7000 feet of climbing. But goddamn it was hot today, plus somehow I underestimated the amount of Gu I had (I only had 3 packets left in my cupboard)... so I got to the bottom of the Sun Top trail and it was like 95 degrees and I was out of food, so I just rode back to my car instead of doing Ranger Creek.

However: Sun Top freakin' rules! I'd never done it before and had no idea what to expect. The climb's a butt-kicker -- something like 3500 feet of climbing in 6 miles, with the steepest part on singletrack at the very end. It gave me a chance to do one of my favorite things, which is ride without my helmet on a slow fire road climb. I'm not saying helmets are bad or not to wear them or whatever, but I really enjoy climbing (slowly) without one, especially when it's hot.

The downhill was amazing. Lots of dips and rises to catch air off of, lots of places to get going very fast, then some more technical switchbacks (one of which I crashed on). I'll post some pictures if my camera survived the crash -- I think it did, but it got pretty dusty.

Ugh. I raced Seward Park last night -- counterclockwise, the "easy" direction -- and got spit out the back with 2 laps to go. I just wasn't feeling it; I did a really hard ride on Wednesday (sprints & hills) and, last night when I was riding down to the park, my legs felt like lead. Sometimes I'll feel terrible at the start of a ride and about 15 minutes in some switch somewhere will be flipped and I'll start feeling great. Not last night, I just kept feeling worse & worse. Coming out of the corner on the 13th lap, I pretty much just gave up and didn't sprint out to stay on the wheel in front of me. Race over.

This was the first time I've ever been tired enough that the ride home hurt. Boy did it.

Tomorrow I'm gonna do the "double crown" -- Sun Top and Ranger Creek (or maybe Palisades if I feel really good). Should be lots of fun.  Today's just recovery and I'm sure I'll feel great by tomorrow morning.  But it has been a hard week.

Tonight Lindsey & her mom & I are going to the Marymoor Velodrome to watch some track racing. There should be some really good riders there because of the ACV races on Saturday & Sunday.

There is nothing better than summer in Seattle. I rode a fast 25 miles this evening after getting home from work in the "heat" (by Seattle's standards, anyway -- less than eighty degrees), got home, drank a smoothie while watching the Tour coverage and now I'm sitting on my couch with all the doors open drinking a beer while a cool breeze blows through the house. And tomorrow I get to get up and do it all over again.

Looks like Armstrong pretty much has the Tour tied up now.  Kind of a bummer -- I would've like to have seen Basso give him more trouble today to set up a killer stage tomorrow.  I still think Ullrich can put himself on the podium, maybe at the expense of Basso.  Tomorrow will still be interesting but it is, sadly, a race for second again.

Lindsey & her mom & I went and saw Riding Giants last night. It's directed by Stacey Peralta, who also did Dogtown & Z-Boys. Riding Giants was great -- interviews with surfing legends combined with some absolutely incredible surfing footage. Makes me want to quit my job and live on a beach somewhere. Really.

Just got back from riding at Tiger Mountain for the second night in a row.  Yesterday I went out & back -- out NW Timber, up Preston, then back.  Tonight I just did the standard loop.
 
Tiger's not my idea of a great ride in any sense at all, really, but it's cool to have something moderately close.  The best part about it is just that I've been riding there for so long -- 11 years now -- that it's really easy to compare my ability and see that I have actually (despite how I feel 99% of the time) improved.  The normal loop used to take me over two hours; tonight I did it in just over an hour.  Also, I used to need to walk in a bunch of places; now I can ride the whole thing, at least in the clockwise/downhill direction.
 
In other news, I've signed up for the Shenandoah Mountain 100 at the beginning of September.  I'm trying to decide if I should do it on my singlespeed; I'm gonna go do a longish SS ride on Sunday and see how I feel after that.  I'd really like to singlespeed the Creampuff next June and the SM100 would be a good lead-up to that.  The downside is that I'm absolutely loving my Kula now and kinda don't want to ride anything else.

Sometimes the best part of a great ride isn't the ride itself. Case in point: yesterday, driving home after a race, all the windows down in my car, coming over Blewett Pass with dramatic clouds looming behind incredible mountains, Neil Young's amazing distorted guitar at max volume, content with everything, no looming questions for the moment -- that felt as good as the race, but the important thing is that it wouldn't have happened without the race before it. I don't know if I've ever experienced that kind of bliss without the context of some sort of athletic endeavor (be it backpacking, mountain biking or road biking), and I don't know if I could.

The race was great too -- short and without the kind of extended climbs that doom me. I finished second and even used a little strategy to beat the guy who finished third -- he was a little stronger than me on climbs but I had him on downhills so I gave it all I could to pass both him and a rider in another class on a false flat right before a long downhill, opened a gap (and forced him to make an awkward pass to get past the other guy) and managed to hold it up the technical climb before the finish. Good stuff.

After the 24 Hour Race at the end of May, my legs felt dead for about 3 weeks, and then it was time for the Creampuff. This week I finally feel like I've got some speed back in my legs, at least to the extent that I've ever had any speed. So last night I decided, at the last minute, to go down and race at Seward Park. It turned out that this was a clockwise night (the direction the race takes around the course alternates weekly) which made me nervous for two reasons: there is a very fast sweeping right-hander at the bottom of the hill which was incredibly sketchy last time I raced in this direction, and last time I raced this direction I got dropped after 7 laps (out of 15).

I was pleasantly surprised, then, that the fast sweeping corner didn't feel at all sketchy. I'm not sure if it's because I was in the pack last night instead of off the back trying to catch up, or if there were fewer sketchy riders in the pack, but I was totally comfortable for the whole race. And, I didn't get dropped. The other thing that's difficult for me about the clockwise route for this race is the sharp hairpin turn where, unless you're right at the front, you lose all your speed, followed by a slight uphill where /everyone/ sprints. I can sprint fine on downhills and flats but I have a lot of trouble coming out of a corner at 12mph and sprinting uphill. Anyway, I did it last night. I felt really good and was very happy to finish with the pack.

Today's a day off the bike. I'm driving out to Wenatchee this afternoon for the penultimate WIM race tomorrow.

I bike-commuted today, for the first time in a while. I've been trying to do more focused training (every time I say that I feel gross) but it really has made a huge difference to make each ride the distance & difficulty I want, rather than just doing the same hilly commute every day. That said, I had a blast today -- I just felt great and had, I think, the fastest homebound commute I've ever had, by about 4 minutes.

I'm back on the bike now, after taking almost a week off. I rode 30 miles Sunday and felt great, then did a quick 15 miler yesterday and felt fast; in fact, the fastest I've felt since before the 24 hour race back in May. I hope this bodes well for my race this weekend -- I'm in 3rd place overall for the Sport Clydesdale class in the WIM series and I'd like to maintain that. I'm aiming for the win this weekend. The course is short, flat & fast which is perfect for me (why I do races like the Creampuff which are the exact antithesis of what I can actually do well I'll never know).

I'm still trying to write a race report for the Creampuff, I swear. I spent some time on it yesterday, between rollin' around on my motorcycle and getting my hair cut and playing endless XBOX basketball with Eric.

Before when I said the hardest thing I've ever done is the Creampuff? Actually that was a lie; trying to write about it is much harder. I love easily defined tasks, like a bike race, where it really is just a matter of plugging away to a set destination. Creative things -- like writing -- are much more difficult for me. I have scoping problems, primarily, I think; I want to write about the Creampuff metaphorically or I want to write about everything all at once or whatever. Maybe I'll try just describing the race itself and go from there.

The hardest thing I've ever done. Well, the hardest thing I've ever done in a day, anyway:

Creampuff results

Whew.

Long report to follow.

It's been a long, long time since the last time I posted. JR has threatened to add a link to this blog (which heretofore was isolated, I think) so I guess I'd better write something.

The Creampuff is this weekend and I've been spending lots of time preparing for that. I've got about 3000 miles in my legs so far this year, including a 24-hour solo singlespeed race, a bunch of 90-100 mile road rides, a few long mountain bike rides and so on. The weather in Oakridge on Sunday looks to be perfect: mid-70s and sun. I'm going to finish it this year, seriously.

I got my new bike built up last week, finally. It is pimpin'! I've been riding the hell out of it and I absolutely love it. I'm psyched to have a bike that really works for me now -- in my two previous attempts at the Creampuff I feel like I was a little hampered by inadequate/poorly-fitting bikes. In 2001, I rode my IF Deluxe which should have been perfect but I could never make it fit me right and it scared the crap out of me on downhills (though it did climb very well). Last year, I got my Kikapu built up literally the day before the race -- the Creampuff was my first ever ride on it. Terrible idea. I love the Kikapu but it's not a perfect bike for the Creampuff; it doesn't climb as well as it should, and I had some mechanical issues as well.

Anyway, I'm feeling great and can't wait for Sunday.

entry.title: A race
entry.content:
Yesterday I did the first WIM race of the season. It was very short -- just 4 laps of a 3.5 mile course, with almost no cliimbing. I've been training lots this spring, but wasn't expecting to do particularly well; I raced two weeks ago down in Capitol Forest and got my ass handed to me by the course and my competitors.

One nice thing about WIM races is the sport classes start at noon. I love being able to sleep in and get a good breakfast on race days. Lindsey & I found a diner-ish place in Spokane (no great feat) and I had french toast, which has always served me well before rides. Then we drove out to the course, soaked up the sun (!), watched the experts race and talked to fellow racers. My teammate Gavin Spomer was there, who has always been stronger than me, and he was riding in the same class as me (Sport Clydesdale) instead of racing singlespeed like he usually does (like me, though, he was riding his singlespeed, just not racing in that class).

At the start, I lined up next to Gavin and he (unsurprisingly) led the sprint towards the first singletrack. One guy got by him right before the singletrack started and got about 30 feet ahead or so. I was one rider behind Gavin on the first winding singletrack section, but feeling very good. As soon as we got onto the uphill dirt road transition (about half a mile into the race), I managed to jump around Gavin and the other rider and keep the leader in sight. The rest of the race was just a matter of trying to keep that guy in sight and make my way around slower/lapped riders. In what might be a first for me, nobody passed me. I was unable to keep the lead rider in sight, which was psychologically very tough, but I stayed focused by thinking about riders who might've been coming up behind me.

By the finish, I still hadn't seen the lead rider. However, the class I raced in gives a time bonus based on your weight (15 seconds X (your weight - 190)). So I wasn't sure how much more I weighed than the guy in front of me (or if I outweighed him), and how far behind him I was. I assumed that I got second, and was really really happy about that. As it turned out, I got first; I outweighed the guy who got first by about 10 pounds and he only finished about 90 seconds in front of me. I won a case of Coeur d'Alene beer, which I can't drink given my newfound straight-edgedness, but Lindsey & Eric are psyched.

entry.title: PBP DNF
entry.content:
Here's a pretty good story about a DNF in the Paris-Brest-Paris. Reading this after DNF'ing the Creampuff last year gets me stoked to try again in June.

Rode 32 miles yesterday, around Mercer Island then down to Seward Park and back. I pushed hard on hills which still resulted in near-glacial slowness. Then I bonked (on a 32 mile ride? Yes). I'm exhausted today, but looking forward to tomorrow's 60 mile road ride. The weather right now is 42 degrees and raining; I hope that improves tomorrow.

Screw running, I'm back on the bike. Two weeks after my foot injury (detailed below) I went on a 12-mile run which was very fun until I stopped running and then could barely walk. I thought it would heal fast but now it's been 17 days and it still hurts (and is impossible to run or ski on), so I guess I've learned some lesson.

Anyway, today was a nice easy 13-mile ride down to Seward Park and back. Boy am I slow, though! Yesterday was a sprint day and I could barely hit 28mph. That's pathetic.

I hired a coach to design me a training schedule. It's nice to have somebody who knows bicycle racing give me advice. My only goal now that the marathon is out of the picture is the Creampuff.

Aargh, my foot hurts. I ran 10 miles on Saturday and on Sunday noticed that the top of my foot was sore when I put on my running shoes just to go for a walk. Then on Tuesday I was stupid and ran 3 miles fast (well, fast for me) on the treadmill. Tuesday night I noticed my foot was creaking! Really. Ugh. So I didn't run yesterday or today and now I'm super antsy and feeling fat and stupid.

In better news, I ordered a 15GB iPod, along with a fancy-pants Vaja case! My old 5GB iPod is in the process of giving up the ghost (halfway into my run on Saturday the battery died, to my chagrin) and the announcement of the mini iPod and the corresponding upping-of-storage at the $299 pricepoint gave me adequate incentive to upgrade.

Holy crap, it's 1:45am and I'm still here at work. Events have been conspiring against me lately, or at least against my ability to ever sleep. Whew.

I've decided to do a marathon in April. I'm freakin' amped! I've been running a fair bit but I definitely need something to focus on and this should do it. The nice thing is that after it's over I'll have time to ramp up for the Creampuff in June, and track cycling throughout the summer. I'm very psyched to do a marathon, though; a year ago I think I would've dismissed it out of hand but now I'm really enjoying running. The weight training that I've done throughout the year has made an amazing difference in my ankle injuries.

entry.title: Panel OKs I-90 transit lanes
entry.content: This could mean the I90 bike lane is closed for two years, and when it re-opens it'll be narrower and traffic will be within two feet of the bike path. Traffic two feet away isn't a big deal if the traffic is going 40 mph; when traffic's moving at 70+mph it's a lot worse. Hopefully this plan will die.

Saturday seems to have turned into my day to write in my blog. I think going on long, moderately fast bike rides puts me in a mood to write (or perhaps puts me in a mood to procrastinate, and writing into the void fulfills that need very well).

Anyway, another great ride this morning with Seattle Velo. It was cold this morning -- 31 degrees when I left the house -- so I think this put everyone in a not-very-fast mood for most of the ride. We just kept a steady 19mph until we got to Mercer Island, then the pace picked up all the way to 20mph. It was a small enough group that everyone stayed together, and we even had a nice rotating paceline going on Rainier. On the last climb a bunch of people pushed pretty hard and I felt good enough to stay with them; I'm very happy about that. If I can just lose another 30 pounds or so, I might actually be back to being a fairly good climber.

Lindsey & I went out for a nice sushi lunch at Bento Box (after wandering around the ID trying to find an open restaurant), and now I'm at work. I'm pretty buried right now and a little worried about scheduling but that is still so much better than having nothing to do.

Another fun weekend of bikes and general slouching about. On Saturday, I went on the team ride with Seattle Velo -- another very fun ride, and while it got fast on Mercer Island it didn't devolve into chaos. It was fun, controlled fast (or maybe it was fun, controlled not-very-fast-but-felt-fast-to-your-out-of-shape-author).

Saturday afternoon, Lindsey & I drove down to Olympia where she started building up her cross bike. Steve sent her a Bianchi Axis frame -- with lugs and everything -- and she's doing it up singlespeed. It looks nice, with green Michelin tires, a Singulator, and a sweet set of Race Face cranks.

Sunday was devoted to being lazy. Eric came over, we watched some football, watched some baseball, then went to the best Ethiopian restaurant I've ever been to. Asimba, right next to Catfish Corner, on MLK & Cherry. So good! $26 for three people, including beer.

I went on the Seattle Velo "Meet the Teams" ride this morning. It started out nice & mellow, 19 or 20mph. I was comfortable. This gave me the thoroughly inaccurate idea that I might actually be in some sort of shape or something.

This illusion was well and truly shattered when we reached Mercer Island, where the ride leader said they might "speed up a bit." One of the new guys decided to jump off the front, and one of the old guys gave chase, and things completely fell apart, for me anyway, from there. I had a good time working with a couple of other riders, but I swear my HR was at 90% for the last half hour.

What's nice is that, as is always the case after an incredibly hard workout, I now feel euphoric and omnipotent. The thing is, though: I feel like I should be able to write incredibly well-crafted words about this feeling; I feel like I should be able to do anything creative with heretofore unknown skill; I feel like I could be the wittiest person at any party -- and yet. My words are the same as ever. The extent of my creativity right now is trying to get the color balance correct on some photos I took 3 years ago. It's 10:15 on a Saturday night and I'm home watching TV and babysitting my scanner. What does that mean?

I guess I'm better off at least feeling good, even if it doesn't change anything outward about me. I know I'll never be a great cyclist (or even a better-than-average one), the act of trying to be one is where the value is. For me.

Christ, maybe the post-ride euphoria does have an effect. It turns me into a blabbering idiot. Enough.

Lindsey's out of town for the weekend, down at Breitenbush Hot Springs with her class for a retreat. So to celebrate my temporary bachelor independence, Eric came over last night and we ate meat. Specifically: steak, seared and then broiled, with a demiglace sauce, and some salad and red wine. Goddamn was it good.

This is a beatiful, beautiful interview:

Fresh Air: Wednesday - October 8, 2003

Listen to Bill O'Reilly lose his shit (and Terry Gross isn't too happy either).

Idle Words
This is an excellent example of the very blog that made me think that this blogging thing might actually be a force for good. Canada! Evil reptilian kitten-eaters! Canada's strongest man!
Seriously.

Latest update on our mouse: Fausto cornered it in the living room on Saturday morning (I knew there was something else exciting that happened on Lindsey's birthday). Above you can see the mouse himself, cowering on top of our bookshelf, and Lindsey, cowering on our coffee table.

Despite having the thing cornered and scared, it somehow escaped from Lindsey, Fausto and I. We haven't seen it since Saturday so perhaps it's decided that it doesn't want to fuck with our 20 pound, FIV+ male tabby. Most likely it's just gone deeper into stealth mode and is stockpiling another enormous pile of turds somewhere.

Also: Saturday was Lindsey's birthday. We didn't actually do a whole lot, except I got up early and bought Lindsey a coffee and a doughnut from The Fargonian, which is our new favorite coffee shop. As far as I can tell, the couple who own it are, in fact, from Fargo but that hasn't stood in the way of making excellent coffee. They make proper ristretto espresso, and even make a Vivace-esque rosetta on their lattes. I speak as if I can properly appreciate coffee but I should add the caveat that all I ever drink is mochas which probably makes me a borderline pariah amongst the coffee cognoscenti.

In the afternoon, prior to the poker tournament from hell, we went to see Spellbound at the Crest ($3 matinees!). It's brilliant.

Yesterday (Sunday) we went to Olympia to go mountain biking with Gio. Unfortunately I was in a foul mood from the minute I woke up; I still can't figure out why. I felt lousy for the entire ride; part of the problem might be that, due to being sick and other random crap, I hadn't been on my bike in THREE WEEKS! That's absolutely stupid. Anyway, it was cool to ride with Gio and it was awesome to see Lindsey have so much fun -- she shadowed me for the first part of the downhill, then just passed me and left me in the dust. What happened? Last time we rode together (um... three weeks ago) she was downhilling like a myopic roadie.

Saturday night, we went over to Mike & Nikki's for a Texas Hold 'Em poker tournament. The deal was: you bought in for $20, then the top 3 (there were 10 players) split the pot, with $120 going to first place, $60 to second and $20 to third. It might've been stressful if I'd stayed in for more than about 8 hands, but as it was I just got to watch most of it.

Josh ended up winning, in a dramatic showdown with Nikki. TJ got third. Lindsey was dominating for the early part of the game but then had a beer, which pushed her over the edge into playing with reckless drunken abandon.

My friend Heather dropped by to visit last night, on her way from Cordova to Santa Fe via New York. I've known Heather since my first day at Evergreen -- we were lab partners in the first class either of us took there -- and we've gone from being great friends (and housemates), to (briefly) really, really disliking each other, back to being really good friends. We've both changed considerably in the 5 years since we met; after her first year at Evergreen, Heather moved to Cordova, initially as an environmental activist. Since then, she's fished (perhaps one of the most bad-ass jobs I've ever heard of), done research for Fish & Game, substitute taught, worked at the Taco Bus (!), and so on. I love seeing Heather and hearing her stories because what she does is so fundamentally different from what I do, but we still relate and get along very well and I think have some fundamental similarities.
I beat this [y20q.net] with "Turing Test". Hmm.

On Saturday night, Lindsey & I went to the Star-Crossed cyclocross race at Marymoor park. This was the first UCI race of the season -- that's right, UCI as in Union Cyclisme Internationale. I had heard a rumor that the 2002 world champion, Erwin Vervecken, was going to be there. He wasn't, but some of the best riders in the country showed up and put on an amazing show. I almost got run over by Adam Craig (who eventually got 2nd) -- I was taking pictures on the outside of a very slippery corner and he leaned, slipped and nearly ran off the course and into me.

Later on, at the same corner, I yelled "Go, Eric" to Eric Atwood who promptly fell over. That sucked.

Tons of people showed up to spectate; according to the organizers, over 1,000! That's amazing for any cycling event, let alone an "underground" sport like 'cross. The course was amazing in many ways, but primarily (as a spectator) because you could see most of it all at once. There was a beer garden, great announcing, and awesome racing. More, please.

I took lots of pictures, some of which I'll hopefully post soon. Here's something I never had to deal with at cycling events before: red-eye. This was only a problem on my digital camera; the flash is offset enough on my SLR to reduce the problem.

Death : Untitled (1993)[www.stevenkatzmanphotography.com]

Despite our regal and completely bad-ass cat, Lindsey & I have had a family of mice living in (or at least regularly raiding) our kitchen for the past couple of weeks. Fausto (our cat) caught a couple of them but appears to have lost interest.

This wouldn't be so bad except that the little fuckers have to shit & piss somewhere, and the somewhere they decided to do this was on the tray on the back of our refrigerator that's meant to collect condensation. It was mouse shit apocalypse back there. Bleach has never seemed a better liquid than it did tonight.

So: tomorrow we buy mouse traps. I never thought I'd do this -- I really thought Fausto would be the end-all, be-all of rodent control, but he's become complacent in his old age. I once watched him corner a bird and eat it and he used to regularly leave shrews on our doormat. Now he sits around and eats and sleeps. No doubt a better literary mind than my own could draw the obvious parallels between your humble scribe and my lazy-ass cat with subtlety and grace; that eludes me now. I will say that I don't feel that I was ever very good at catching birds or leaving grisly presents, metaphorical or no.

Nice article about Paris-Brest-Paris in the Port Townsend paper: One way to see France: 760 miles, three days, two legs, one bicycle [www.ptleader.com]

There are a few (OK, a lot of) things I'd like to do on my bike before I die: Alaska to Argentina, Ruta de los Conquistadores, maybe a round-the-world ride, and PBP. PBP has the history, the spectators, and the cheese and wine.

I'm re-installing my OS for the third time today. This sucks and leads to lots of time spent browsing the web on my other machine. In fact I just found my friend Nikki's blog.

For reasons that are unclear to me, when my computers are busy I find myself thinking I'm busy. So while my little Toshiba churns away sucking bits down from the corpnet, I go idle. Weird. It's hard to test my code with a non-functional test machine, so I'll let that stand as my excuse.

I got a new camera the other day, a Canon S400. Its primary appeal is its size, or lack of it. It's so tiny! Hopefully this will mean it comes with me on mountain bike rides and skiing trips.

I still love my N90, but its weight and bulk make it very difficult to carry while cycling. Also, I love shooting slide film, but getting the film scanned is kind of a pain in the butt. So I'm hoping that the S400 will lead to lots more practice shooting which will hopefully result in better quality. One day Lindsey & I will do this, and I'd like to have the skills to keep a good photographic journal.

Alright, so it really was just that easy to get this new-fangled "blogger" thing up and running. So now, dear reader, you shall be subject to my desultory ramblings until such time as you stop reading.

Perhaps I'll use this space to give vent to my creative wordplay. Most likely it'll become a dusty and cobweb-infested snapshot of a time when I thought that writing a journal on the web might be a good idea. Only time will tell.

entry.title: Joel was talking about how sleep and hibernate can...
entry.content:
Joel was talking about how sleep and hibernate can be merged. The Mac does this nicely. There is only one choice, "Sleep." At least with laptops, it hibertates the machine (writes RAM to disk) but then actually sleeps. That way, in case the power goes away by the battery wearing down, you just wake up as if you had been hibernating all along. (You can test this by sleeping a Macbook and then removing the battery. I don't feel like unplugging my iMac to see if it works the same way.) And if you never run out of power, you get the advantage of a fast wake-up time.

This seems to be the right solution 90% of the time. For those geeks that really want only sleep or only hibernate for some reason, they can hack away and change the default behavior. (It's fairly easy to do.)

This is why I like my Mac so much. Instead of bogging me down with pointless choices, it just does things the one best way.

disclaimer - I was a manager at Microsoft during some of this period (a member of the class of 17 uninformed decision makers) although not on this feature, er, menu.

The people who designed the source control system for Windows were *not* idiots. They were trying to solve the following problem:
- thousands of developers,
- promiscuous dependency taking between parts of Windows without much analysis of the consequences
--> with a single codebase, if each developer broke the build once every two years there would never be a Longhorn build (or some such statistic - I forget the actual number)

There are three obvious solutions to this problem:
1. federate out the source tree, and pay the forward and reverse integration taxes (primarily delay in finding build breaks), or...
2. remove a large number of the unneccesary dependencies between the various parts of Windows, especially the circular dependencies.
3. Both 1&2
#1 was the winning solution in large part because it could be executed by a small team over a defined period of time. #2 would have required herding all the Windows developers (and PMs, managers, UI designers...), and is potentially an unbounded problem.

(There was much work done analyzing the internal structure of Windows, which certainly counts as a Microsoft trade secret so I am not at liberty to discuss it)

Note: the open source community does not have this problem (at least not to the same degree) as they tend not to take dependencies on each other to the same degree, specifically:
- rarely take dependencies on unshipped code
- rarely make circular dependencies
- mostly take depemdencies on mature stable components.

As others have mentioned, the real surprise here is that they managed to ship anything.

entry.content:
Disclaimer - I'm a current dev on Windows.

It's absolutely true that a deep tree tends to increase the time it take a piece of code to migrate up to root and back down to farthest out branches - but that's not the problem. Slavish adherence to the "rules" as a means of CYA, a desire to build kingdoms (people/hardware/process), an inability to adjust as circumstances changed, and an irrational fear of breaking "something" were the real problems with many branches in Vista.

So what if you were 4 steps away - that's exactly where you should have been if you were working on a destabilizing area with a small team. However, once your code was relatively complete - your branch should have been orphaned and you should have moved up one level - if necessary, creating another branch 3 steps from root. And when that branch was essentially done, you should have moved 2 branches from root. If you had to take on destabilizing changes again, you go down a level. The key is to be flexible, be aware of where you were in the dev cycle, adjust accordingly, and understand the REAL impact when something breaks(every break is not the same). Some teams managed to do exactly this - many didn't. This isn't difficult - but teams constantly harped on BS "rules" as the reason why they couldn't move or make progress. "My PM tells me what bugs I can/can't work on". "I can only check into branch vvv_www_xxx_yyy_zzz - I have no idea if/when my changes will migrate up". "We need a N-week test pass before we're allowed to make a change - there's no way we could do that in any other branch".

I see exactly the reverse happening now. "Deep is bad" and "Every branch should be off root" are the new mantra. It will result in failure as well because it fails to take into account how software is written under some belief that "this time it's different". Depth protects the root early in the cycle, allows batching of destabilizing changes (and more importantly dev/test/triage resources). It will fail when a milestone approaches and every branch wants to integrate up at once. It will also fail as everyone will feel the need to 'bulk up' so they can run off root - and once you do so, it's incredibly difficult to ever slim down.

entry.title: The tiering of the source code is not a new approa...
entry.content:
The tiering of the source code is not a new approach, people have been trying things like that since the 70s, and always come away with the firm conviction that the people before them were right (you shouldn't do it). It is an encoding of the very saurian project management that toppled IBM.

The solution is out there, and has been, for some time. I'm not talking about a specific instance, because frankly I've grown to like SourceSafe for the way it handles cross-dependencies (links).

Its a three part solution: 1. RCS style branching (where branches aren't repository copies), 2. encapsulation of the tiering within the source control environment, 3. automated acceptance testing.

Many game development companies use a technique whereby developers can check in code that might break the project only to a new branch; this gives them opportunity to share a change with a limited pool of other developers who have to write the code neccessary to complete it. When the project is done and ready for review/testing, they merge the branch up *themselves*.

The source-code system then performs acceptance testing on the code changes when you try to merge a branch. That is, it tries to build the code base that would result, and refuses the merge if the resulting code won't compile.

IMHO the real issue is much simpler than any of this; its a problem that every software developer working under Windows gets to share in the agony of: Microsoft allows itself to blur the line between its products. While I realize that the programmer who decides to make a particular change is probably trying to Do The Right thing, it seems to be that decisions get *approved* for different reasons. Tweak the OS here to make something in Excel cooler ought to only occur when that tweak is generally good for the OS. entry.title: So Joel Spolsky slips back into a Microsoft Progra...
entry.content:
So Joel Spolsky slips back into a Microsoft Program Management (PM) role and decides to write a spec for the power button on the Vista Start menu. The reason he spent the time doing this is because he felt the number of options provided, 9 were excessive and confusing to most users. His spec comes down to:

"So now we've got exactly one log off button left. Call it "b'bye". When you click b'bye, the screen is locked and any RAM that hasn't already been copied out to flash is written. You can log back on, or anyone else can log on and get their own session, or you can unplug the whole computer."

Now if Joel actually clicked on the Vista Start button and then looked at the options presented before expanding the 'advanced' list of options then he would've realized that in fact the implementation in Vista is virtually identical to what he ended up specifying.

To the normal user there are really just 2 options, a 'Power' button and a 'Lock' button, which have tool tips that explain what they do.

Now on my desktop PC with a default install of Vista the Sleep option is a new hybrid sleep implementation which is really a combination of hibernate and sleep. When the PC goes to sleep, either based on an explicit user request or because it has been idle for 1 hour then Vista writes out any necessary RAM pages to disk as it would for a hibernate, but then instead of switching off it goes into sleep mode. The advantage of this scheme is that if there is a power failure (environment, cord unplugged accidentally or on purpose) then when the PC is powered on again it performs a hibernate resume. I've actually experienced this first hand with a recent power failure and it was really useful to get back to all my open applications etc. after the power failure.

Now in addition when the PC resumes from sleep in this scheme you are presented with a login screen, and if Joel had taken a look he would've also noticed a 'Switch User' button on this logon screen just below the password edit control.

So this default scheme is pretty darn close to what Joel has specified as his ideal UI, it really just has 1 extra option, the 'Lock' button.

The main issue I think is that Joel hasn't approached this as 'regular' user, but rather more as an advanced/power user who has decided to click on the advanced list which is shown when you click/hover over the '>' button. So Vista has provided the simplicity for regular users and has made an advanced list of options available for more advanced users. Now what may have been a more useful posting/debate is whether this advanced list is too easily accessible to regular users by accident, e.g. should it maybe only show up if say the 'alt' key is held down like a lot of the menu bars in Vista applications.

entry.title: I found the description of the "partitioned" sourc...
entry.content:
I found the description of the "partitioned" source code management setup to be illuminating, because it explains a major issue: monolithic design.

I've worked in other environments where code integration was fraught with peril, though the actual population of developers was small enough that they'd be "right there" for integration & test builds, confirming that their changes didn't disrupt the working of the target system.

Consider that Linux, despite being a "monolithic" kernel, has a fair degree of compartmentalization between component parts-- syscalls, devices drivers, etc-- and the GUI isn't part of the critical code of the operating system itself.

It has been argued that Windows has the GUI integrated into the kernel to ensure that it *has* to be there, despite the roots of NT being from DEC VMS, which means that *any* change by a wide array of developers, once integrated into the "build" system, can create an "unbuildable" system... and, with the number of changes potentially being integrated on a daily basis, I'd bet that they don't want to call in all of the authors of the daily change set together to work out which code "broke" the build since this'd be a daily "critical" call.

When the S/W you're doing builds for doesn't have a sh!tload of cross-dependencies (i.e. "small kernel" and lots of user-level apps) this isn't as much of a problem.

Way back when on the UNIVAC mainframes we had source control via the SSG processor and sidelines consisting of PCFs and TCFs that would be merged into our builds and it took a while for a sideline to get merged into the "main" TCF (Temporary Correction File). It could take months or more for your fixes to be merged into the PCF (Permanent Correction File) and, to my limited knowledge, I'm not sure any changes ever got graduated to the MAIN (root) code. This system also maintained several levels of fallback...

...but that was a much smaller system which had much better code compartmentalization than we have been hearing about.

New Orleans was poorly compartmentalized, by the way. I think we can see why security breaches are so dangerous w/ Windows.

The goal of limited choices is a good one but like everything about UI design or programming it is not dogma.

What really gets me about the sort of UI gurus who like to pontificate on the net is that they take a generally good practice and then take it to ridiculous extremes.

Simplifying the shutdown/restart stuff is a good idea. I like the way the mac integrates sleep and hibernate. Three options in the default configuration: sleep, restart, power off are good. One certainly wants to reduce the number of apparent options but trying to remove restart is just silly slavish devotion to the rule of 'remove options'.

I mean more options are only a problem when they are apparently salient options. If I know I want to step away from my computer having to choose between sleep and hibernate might cause confusion. But when I go to the start menu I have a definite idea about whether I want to restart or power off so what's the problem.

Also the idea that being usable for my mom means it has to be frustrating for a power user is just dumb. Additional settings that allow more options to be displayed or advanced menus are good things so long as they aren't *salient* options to the regular user. Once again the Mac is a perfect example of this. I despised Macs for a long time because they were just too dumbed down but with OS X they manage to retain the simplicity for the average user while combining it with the control and features any UNIX hacker would love.

The problem with things like advanced options in most software programs is that they aren't used consistently. Too often the normal user has to go to the advanced menu to do something. Then once you've sent the user to the advanced menu for one thing it is too easy to achieve false simplicity in your main menu by shifting functionality to the advanced menu that normal users need.

I get the feeling what tends to happen is this. Some UI guy applies the generally good principle of simplicity and tells the menu design people that they have too many options and need to get rid of the restart option. They take his advice but knowing that forcing everyone to power on and off would really annoy some people (especially if the physical on switch isn't easily accessible) they shift it to the advanced menu. Now all the normal users who want to restart look around and when they can't find it look in the advanced menu. But now the advanced options are no non-salient, normal users realize they need to look there for basic functionality and now they are made unhappy by all the confusing options there.

While no rule should be followed slavishly I think there is a good rule of thumb for this. If you can imagine your grandma saying, "How do I just X" and you answering "go into the advanced menu and click X" then something is wrong.

--

Ultimately the real lesson I'm learning from all these comments is that you really need dictators. Whatever solution one guy comes up with for the menu is going to be better than what the committee comes up with.

In locked mode, your email still arrives; your documents keep printing; your code keeps compiling...

The description of engineering practices sounds like a mess when Microsoft bit off more than it could chew with 1000s of developers using the same process of checking in code. Something tells me they'll try and fix this for vNext...

entry.title: [i]The people who designed the source control syst...
entry.content:
[i]The people who designed the source control system for Windows were *not* idiots. They were trying to solve the following problem:
- thousands of developers,
- promiscuous dependency taking between parts of Windows without much analysis of the consequences[/i]

Why don't they do some "pipelining"?

For example, have a kernel development team that constantly builds kernels without worrying much about anyone else. When the kernel is complete/stable, they pass it off to the next stage of the pipeline, and start the next version of the kernel.

Then you'd have other teams doing the same thing - a GUI team repeatedly writing/adapting the GUI for each new kernel that comes down the line, a few teams doing "legacy" APIs, a few(?) teams doing drivers, etc.

At any time you could have several versions of Windows coming down the pipeline, but at each stage the "foundation code" that each team is relying on is (mostly) stable, static code, so they don't need to be constantly adjusting their work because of changes made "upstream".

At first glance this looks like it'd effect flexibility, but if there were 3 stages on an 18 month cycle, then it'd only take 3 years for a new feature to go from "kernel team sign off" to a released product with the new feature (better than consumers see now), and you'd be releasing a new version every 18 months (much better than consumers see now).

Anyway, in this case you'd have a source control system for each stage, and half the dependancy problems wouldn't occur to begin with.

Of course there would be practical problems with this (especially with a monolithic "everything including your grandmother" kernel), but Microsoft do seem to be aware of these sorts of dependancy problems, and do seem to be at least attempting to fix them.

"The problems I saw weren't because of any incompetence on the micro scale or even anything attributable to just one person; the slowness and indecision were emergent properties of the system."

Yes!

Up until I worked at DoubleClick, I had no idea how stuff like this could go so wrong unless everyone involved was incompetant, lazy, or both.

Up until DoubeClick, tho, my largest company was RCN, and the developers there consisted of approximately 5 people (sometimes 4, up to 6) in a small dark room who had complete autonomy.

Before that, it was Panix, and there the developers consisted of: me. Autonomy barely describes it.

I'm guessing that I'm not the only one who's vision is colored by working for smaller types of companies, or at least smaller types of development teams.

Almost without fail, everyone at DoubleClick is extremely bright, compentant, and hard-working. Yet the quality of the code, the consistency of the features, the usability of the UI suffers. The fact that it works at all is a testament to just how good the people I work with are.

Sounds like an oxymoron, non? Yet it's completely true. I've worked with some very bright people (hopefully Panix still means something these days), but DoubleClick is the only place where people are so consistently bright. And hard working. You'd have to be: it's hard to do everything, and figuring out how to get through all the landmines in front of you takes enormous creativity.

I'm not sure exactly where the problem lies. As you say, I think it's more of an emergent property. Lots of things which are only slightly bad with 5 people are marjorly bad with 12 different teams of 5 to 10 people, all inter-related. And compared to MS, I'm sure we've got it easy. If I need something done, I can frequently walk over to a cube or five and get it done without involving a meeting. Sometimes. Although that's less and less possible.

Plus we have people from India doing a whole lot of work for us, so there's an enormous lag when dealing with them. Luckily, they're all really good and clever, too, so things are still possible.

Which is perhaps part of the problem: management overhead's increasing neccessity, coupled with the (at least polynomial, but I suspect factorially) increasing delay overhead.

While the latter may be self-apparent, the former at least is unproven (as far as I've seen). Maybe you don't need so much management, but that certainly seems to be the way things operate. I count myself lucky to have as little as I do.

And let's not place all the blame on managers (although, honestly, it's not even their fault, it's a property of their work). Part of the problem, as well, is entrenched code base. Ours is ten years old, which is fairly old in the scheme of things. Again, it's not MS, but it's older than perl (in any meaningful sense). We have entrenched clients who have their own costs if we decide to break something incompatibly.

Ruby's got it easy. Spolsky has it really easy. Which I wish he'd realize, instead of acting like it's the only possible world that makes sense.

entry.title: The analogy I use when describing how people learn...
entry.content:
The analogy I use when describing how people learn to code is blacksmithing. There are a few reasons this works, but I think the best one is that writing software seems to be best learned via apprenticeship.

Hand-crafted things have some pretty significant downsides. You already mentioned cost. I'd love to ride on a Rivendell bike frame, but it'd cost ten times what a new steel frame would. But there's also reliability.

A handmade knife is likely to be reliable, because the only people who buy handmade knives care a lot about their quality, and because handmade knives are basically only made out of really good materials to begin with. (This is the "macro lens" argument I think we discussed at one point.) A handmade audio amplifier, though... reliability wise, you're better off with a Sony, because the guys in the garage building the boutique amps can't tool up for proper QA. Software, it seems to me, is more like an amp than a pocketknife in this regard.

Software of course exhibits shitty reliability and cost in general, much like other hand-made products.

For pocketknives and bike frames, I think I'll stick with my mundane Benchmade and machine-welded Jamis. So why would I like to ride on a Rivendell? Well, they elicit the same emotional response in me you get from your Laguiole; they're beautiful and they're exclusive. It's snob appeal - an irrational impulse, but one not to be underestimated.

entry.title: While not exactly related to abstraction alone, on...
entry.content:
While not exactly related to abstraction alone, one of my "guiding quotes" as a developer is this:
"More computing sins are committed in the name of efficiency (without necessarily achieving it) than for any other single reason - including blind stupidity." - W.A. Wulf

Maybe one reason is that education as a programmer is either mostly "learning by doing" (the auto-didactic hard way) or very abstract (no pun intended), formal (the "applied mathematics" way of some unis). If you get told for years to plan, create abstract bases, design, draw clouds and UML; that leaves its traces in your mind. The first group writes code that is ugly and does nearly no abstraction at all, which is also not desireable, but these application are focused on single task. They may be hard to extend, but they ship. There are applications that are code monsters, unabstracted, monolithic blocks of C++/C mixture, but the run, ship and earn money. And there are wonderful visions like Chandler (and yes, Outlook to some extend) and others. Beautiful castles of marble layers, abstracted to death that will never reach the magical "RTM" status. While I currently only develop small portions of code (everybody get promoted until he reaches his personal level of incompetence ;-) ), my goal is to find the equilibrium between these two schools of thought. Learning from my experience with my little baby daughter (greetings to Amelia!) make me see that knowledge starts with instances, concrete entities of the real world. "Cat, cat, cat". Then, slowly you start recognizing there are common patterns, generalizations, "abstract classes". Now you see that catsm, lions, cheetahs, they're all cats actually :-)
To abstract and to optimize, you have to have something that is abstractable or optimizable.
Well, that ends my two cents. And being no native speaker, if you want to edit / shorten my comment, please feel free to do so.

entry.title: Pipelining of a sort was the initial goal of the V...
entry.content:
Pipelining of a sort was the initial goal of the VBL model. Groups were to start with a common source base, a well defined and working set of common baseline tests and common baseline hardware in the virtual build labs and a well defined set of RI quality benchmarks that would only allow ship quality code to migrate to the main branch.

The respective groups were to do their feature work and produce daily builds for consumption and test within their group. As they got closer to feature complete, the code churn rate was to reduce, the quality of the internal builds were expected to rise to ship quality and then they were expected to raise the "we're ready" flag and RI to the main branch. This would allow for smaller, more flexible teams that could turn and burn code at a much faster rate than what ended up happening at the end of win2k. What was to supposed to happen was shipping quality code coming into the main lab at each and every RI.

The problems that arose that bit this model in the ass: Management did not have any means by which to measure a main build since the first RI might not happen for months. Common baseline tests did not exist (funny how that wasn't brought to anyone's attention until win2k was shipped), no RI quality criteria.

The biggest nightmare was the management nervousness. The other issues we could have and were working to overcome. Given the nervous state of affairs, the plan for the model was largely abandoned and RI's were done on a scheduled frequency basis (usually two weeks) for each VBL. Hardly time to cook new code in the test org and still manage to keep to your feature test plan. Lots of randomization, lots of half baked code being introduced into the main build and then infecting the other VBL's.

Of course broken functionality in one branch leads to all kinds of hell in other branches, and then of course you had fixes for those problems being introduced "cross branch" and that caused all kinds of other headaches (baseless integrations and such, poor/no history of where the code came from or how).

Patience is golden. What eventually became WindowsXP was not.

The reason it came out as good as it did was the long soak time on the main build at the end. At that point all code work on WS03 was halted and ALL resources were to be committed to XP (even teams that had little to no contribution to XP). My team sat essentially idle for the better of 45 days before mgmt. relented and let us get back to work doing something that would let us earn our paychecks. Incredible waste, but with direct injection of code fixes into the main build, things stabilized and eventually shipped.

The Vista debacle has pretty well been outlined already. In essence, we changed course midstream, once again, tossing the baby with the bath water. Incredible waste again. Big plans, big goals, no heart to see it thru to the end, but scared enough to run back to a comfort zone and start over from there.

And the comment about Brian T. is about as true as it gets. There have always been a handful of truly dedicated people who you always go to when you need a job done and done right. Unfortunately, the number of those people are fewer now while the number of hand wavers just seems to continue to grow.

If there was a magic potion that could turn power point decks into real code....

Former softie, ain't never going back...

entry.title: From reading most of this rather long blog, it com...
entry.content:
From reading most of this rather long blog, it comes clear that M$ has blurred the levels of software. Remember the Multics "rings". They were rather well defined. You did some stuff in ring 0, you did other stuff in ring 3 (and did nothing in ring 1 or 2 as it ended up).

If there are "multiple dependencies" then the ring's edges have been violated. That will, indeed, cause problems and extreme delays.

Normally, if you want a service from the kernel, request it. It will be added or a previous service expanded without invalidating the features the service provided to previous, established users. Then you add your update to your "ring" and all is well. You don't have to wait on someone else's update unless it is the SAME update you need. Then you are both happy when it comes along but there are no "deadly embrases" that need a dictator to resolve.

As soon as the ring boundaries are breached and groups start waiting on groups instead of waiting on the next ring up, you will grind to a halt.

From what I read, it appears that this separation has been violated and this will cause exactly the problems that are being seen.

Too bad. Anarchy is not a good thing in a mature product(?) or company.

This from 30 years of doing this programming gig and watching how things can devolve into chaos.

Mike Morrow
